sprouts

Interface Val<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of the item held by this Val.
    All Superinterfaces:
    Observable
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Result<V>, Var<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractVariable, ResultImpl

    public interface Val<T>
extends Observable
    A read only view on a wrapped item which can be observed for changes using Actions registered through the onChange(Channel, Action) method, where the Channel is used to distinguish between changes from different sources (usually application layers like the view model or the view). The API of this is very similar to the Optional API in the sense that it is a null safe wrapper around a single item, which may also be missing (null).

    The Channel supplied to the onChange(Channel, Action) method to register an Action callback is expected to be a simple constant, usually one of the From constants like for example From.VIEW_MODEL or From.VIEW. You may fire a change event for a particular channel using the fireChange(Channel) method or in case the property is also a mutable Var, then through the Var.set(Channel, Object).
    Note that Var.set(Object) method defaults to the From.VIEW_MODEL channel.

    If you no longer need to observe changes on this property, then you can remove the registered Action callback using the Observable.unsubscribe(Subscriber) method (Action is also a Subscriber).

    Note that the name of this class is short for "value". This name was deliberately chosen because it is short, concise and yet clearly conveys the same meaning as other names used to model this kind of pattern, like "property", "observable object", "observable value", "observable property", etc. Using Var and Val as names also allows for the distinction between mutable and immutable properties without having to resort to prefixes like "mutable" or "immutable" as part of types that are supposed to be used everywhere in your code.

    Please take a look at the living sprouts documentation where you can browse a large collection of examples demonstrating how to use the API of this class.

    See Also:
    A mutable subclass of this class.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Default Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean allowsNull()
      A property will only allow null items if it was constructed with a "ofNullable(..)" factory method.
      static boolean equals(@Nullable java.lang.Object o1, @Nullable java.lang.Object o2)
      Val and Var implementations are expected to represent simple wrappers for data centric quasi value types! So two primitive arrays of integers for example would not be recognized as equal when calling one of their Object.equals(Object) methods because the method does not compare the contents of the two arrays, it compares the identities of the arrays! This method defines what it means for 2 property items to be equal.
      Val<T> fireChange(Channel channel)
      Triggers all observer lambdas for the given Channel.
      default T get()
      This method is intended to be used for when you want to wrap non-nullable types.
      static int hashCode(java.lang.Object o)
      Val and Var implementations require their own Object.hashCode() method because they are supposed to be viewed as data centric quasi value types! So two arrays of integer for example would not have the same hash code when calling Object.hashCode() on them.
      default boolean hasID()
      A convenient method to check if this property has been assigned an id.
      default boolean hasNoID()
      A convenient method to check if this property has not been assigned an id.
      java.lang.String id()
      Returns the name/id of the property which is useful for debugging as well as persisting their state by using them as keys for whatever storage data structure one chooses.
      default void ifPresent(java.util.function.Consumer<T> action)
      If an item is present, performs the given action with the item, otherwise does nothing.
      default void ifPresentOrElse(java.util.function.Consumer<? super T> action, java.lang.Runnable emptyAction)
      If an item is present, performs the given action with the item, otherwise performs the given empty-based action.
      default boolean is(T otherItem)
      This method check if the provided item is equal to the item wrapped by this Var instance.
      default boolean is(Val<T> other)
      This method check if the item by the provided property is equal to the item wrapped by this Var instance.

      If an item is not present, returns true, otherwise false.
      default boolean isNot(T otherItem)
      This method check if the provided item is not equal to the item wrapped by this Val instance.

      This method check if the item of the provided property is not equal to the item wrapped by this Val instance.
      default boolean isOneOf(T first, T second, T... otherValues)
      This method checks if at least one of the provided items is equal to the item wrapped by this Var instance.
      default boolean isOneOf(Val<T> first, Val<T> second, Val<T>... otherValues)
      This checks if at least one of the items of the provided properties is equal to the item wrapped by this Var instance.
      default boolean isPresent()
      If an item is present, returns true, otherwise false.
      default java.lang.String itemAsString()
      This method simply returns a String representation of the wrapped item which would otherwise be accessed via the orElseThrow() method.

      • ofNullable

        static <T> Val<T> ofNullable(java.lang.Class<T> type,
                             T item)
        Use this factory method to create a new Val instance whose item may or may not be null.

        Example: 

        
      Val.ofNullable(String.class, null);

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the wrapped item.
        Parameters:
        type - The type of the item wrapped by the property. This is used to check if the item is of the correct type.
        item - The initial item of the property. This may be null.
        Returns:
        A new Val instance.

      • ofNull

        static <T> Val<T> ofNull(java.lang.Class<T> type)
        A more concise version of ofNullable(Class, Object) which is equivalent to Var.ofNullable(type, null).
        The Val instances returned by this factory method, are nullable, which means their allowsNull() method will always yield true.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the wrapped item.
        Parameters:
        type - The type of the item wrapped by the property.
        Returns:
        A new Val instance.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the item held by the Val!
        Parameters:
        item - The initial item of the property which must not be null.
        Returns:
        A new Val instance wrapping the given item.

      • of

        static <T> Val<T> of(Val<T> toBeCopied)

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • of

        static <T> Val<T> of(Val<T> first,
                     Val<T> second,
                     java.util.function.BiFunction<T,T,T> combiner)
        Creates a read only Val property that constitutes a live view of the two given properties using a combiner function, which takes in the items of the two properties and returns an updated item based on them.
        The combiner function is invoked to compute a new item for the view property whenever at least one of the items in the two properties changes, or whenever a manual change event is fired (see fireChange(Channel)) on either one...

        Note the property view does not permit storing null references! So if the combiner function returns a null reference on the first call, a NullPointerException will be thrown. If a null reference is returned on subsequent calls, the view will log a warning and simply retain the last non-null value!
        If you need a composite view which allows null, use the ofNullable(Val, Val, BiFunction) method instead.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the items held by the properties.
        Parameters:
        first - The first property to be combined with the second property.
        second - The second property to be combined with the first property.
        combiner - The function used to combine the items of the two properties, where the first argument is the item of the first property and the second argument is the item of the second property.
        Returns:
        A new Val instance which is a live view of the two given properties.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the combiner function returns a null reference when it is first called.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the types of the two properties are not compatible.

      • ofNullable

        static <T> Val<T> ofNullable(Val<T> first,
                             Val<T> second,
                             java.util.function.BiFunction<T,T,T> combiner)
        Creates a read only Val property that constitutes a live view of the two given properties using a combiner function, which takes in the items of the two properties and returns an updated item based on them.
        The combiner function is invoked to compute a new item for the view property whenever at least one of the items of the two properties change, or whenever a manual change event is fired (see fireChange(Channel)).

        Note that this property does permit storing null references.
        If you need a composite view which does not permit null, use the of(Val, Val, BiFunction) method instead.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the items held by the properties.
        Parameters:
        first - The first property to be combined with the second property.
        second - The second property to be combined with the first property.
        combiner - The function used to combine the items of the two properties, where the first argument is the item of the first property and the second argument is the item of the second property.
        Returns:
        A new Val instance which is a live view of the two given properties.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the combiner function returns a null reference when it is first called.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the types of the two properties are not compatible.

      • get

        default T get()
        This method is intended to be used for when you want to wrap non-nullable types. So if an item is present (not null), it returns the item, otherwise however NoSuchElementException will be thrown. If you simply want to get the item of this property irrespective of it being null or not, use orElseNull() to avoid an exception. However, if this property wraps a nullable type, which is not intended to be null, please use orElseThrow() to make this intention clear. The orElseThrow() method is functionally identical to this method.
        Returns:
        the non-null item described by this Val
        Throws:
        java.util.NoSuchElementException - if no item is present

        A live view of the presence of an item in this property in the form of a Boolean property. So whenever the isPresent() flag of this property changes, the item of the returned property will be updated to reflect the change.

      • map

        Val<T> map(java.util.function.Function<T,T> mapper)
        If the item is present, applies the provided mapping function to it, and returns it wrapped in a new Val instance.
        If the item is not present, then an empty Val instance is returned.

        But note that the resulting property does not constitute a live view of this property and will not be updated when this property changes.
        It is functionally very similar to the Optional.map(Function) method.

        If you want to map to a property which is an automatically updated live view of this property, then use the view(Function) method instead. This is essentially the same as Optional.map(Function) but based on Val as the wrapper instead of Optional.

        Parameters:
        mapper - the mapping function to apply to an item, if present
        Returns:
        A new property either empty (containing null) or containing the result of applying the mapping function to the item of this property.

      • mapTo

        <U> Val<U> mapTo(java.lang.Class<U> type,
                 java.util.function.Function<T,U> mapper)
        If the item is present, applies the provided mapping function to it, and returns it wrapped in a new Val instance.
        If the item is not present, then an empty Val instance is returned.

        But note that the resulting property does not constitute a live view of this property and will not be updated when this property changes.
        It is functionally very similar to the Optional.map(Function) method.

        If you want to map to a property which is an automatically updated live view of this property, then use the viewAs(Class, Function) method instead.

        Type Parameters:
        U - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
        Parameters:
        type - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
        mapper - the mapping function to apply to an item, if present
        Returns:
        A new property either empty (containing null) or containing the result of applying the mapping function to the item of this property.

      • viewAs

        <U> Val<U> viewAs(java.lang.Class<U> type,
                  java.util.function.Function<T,U> mapper)
        Use this to create a live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function.
        So whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will be updated based on the mapping function.

        Note that this method will try to map value based item types like String, Integer, Double, etc. to the default value of their respective primitive types, if the provided mapping function returns a null reference.
        So for example, if this is a wrapper for a property of type Integer, and the mapping function returns a null reference, then the resulting view property will always contain the value 0 and its allowsNull() method will always return false.

        The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of the UI of an application, where null may lead to exceptions and ultimately confusing user experiences.

        Also note that a property view may only contain null if the property it is based on was created with the "ofNullable(...)" factory method (in which case its allowsNull() method will return true). Otherwise, it will throw an exception when trying to map a null reference.

        Type Parameters:
        U - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
        Parameters:
        type - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
        mapper - the mapping function to apply to an item, if present
        Returns:
        A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

      • view

        default Val<T> view(java.util.function.Function<T,T> mapper)
        Use this to create a live view of this property based on a mapping function which maps the item of this property to an item of the same type as this property. So whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will be updated based on the mapping function. If you want to create a live view of a different type, use the viewAs(Class, Function) method instead.

        Note that this method will try to map value based item types like String, Integer, Double, etc. to the default value (or "null object") of their respective types, if the provided mapping function returns a null reference.
        So if the type of this property is a String, and the mapping function returns a null reference, then the resulting view property will always contain an empty string and its allowsNull() method will always return false.

        Also note that a property view may only contain null if the property it is based on was created with the "ofNullable(...)" factory method (in which case its allowsNull() method will return true). Otherwise, it will throw an exception when trying to map a null reference.

        Parameters:
        mapper - the mapping function to apply to an item, if present
        Returns:
        A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

      • viewAsString

        default Val<java.lang.String> viewAsString(java.util.function.Function<T,java.lang.String> mapper)
        Use this to create a String based live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function where the item of this property is mapped to a String. This means that whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will also be updated based on the result of the mapping function.

        Note that null references inside the viewed property will always be mapped to the "null object" of the String type, which is an empty string.
        This means that the resulting view can never contain null and its allowsNull() method will always return false.

        The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of the UI of an application, where null may lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing or erroneous user experience.

        Parameters:
        mapper - The mapping function to turn the item of this property to a String, if present
        Returns:
        A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

      • viewAsString

        default Val<java.lang.String> viewAsString()
        Use this to create a String based live view of this property through a new property based on the Object.toString() method used as the mapping function.
        Whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will be recomputed by sending the item of this property to the Object.toString() method and using the result as the new item of the view property.

        Note that null references inside the viewed property will always be mapped to the "null object" of the String type, which is an empty string.
        This means that the resulting view can never contain null and its allowsNull() method will always return false.

        The avoidance of null references in the view is a design decision based on the assumption that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of the UI of an application, where null may lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing or error-prone user experience.

        Returns:
        A String property that is a live view of this property.

      • viewAsDouble

        default Val<java.lang.Double> viewAsDouble(java.util.function.Function<T,java.lang.Double> mapper)
        Use this to create a Double based live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function. So whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will be recomputed based on the result of the mapping function.

        Note that null references inside the viewed property will always be mapped to the "null object" of the Double type, which is 0.0.
        This means that the resulting view can never contain null and its allowsNull() method will always return false.

        Null is deliberately avoided in the view because the view of a property is intended to be used as part of the UI of an application, where null may lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing or erroneous user experience.

        In case of an exception being thrown by the mapping function, the resulting view will contain Double.NaN to indicate that the mapping function failed to map the item of this property to a Double.

        Parameters:
        mapper - the mapping function to turn the item of this property to a Double, if present
        Returns:
        A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

      • viewAsDouble

        default Val<java.lang.Double> viewAsDouble()
        Use this to create a Double based live view of this property whose item is dynamically computed based on the Object.toString() and Double.parseDouble(String) methods. If the String cannot be parsed to a Double, the item of the property will be Double.NaN.

        Note that null references inside the viewed property will always be mapped to the "null object" of the Double type, which is 0.0.
        This means that the resulting view can never contain null and its allowsNull() method will always return false.

        Null is deliberately avoided in the view because the view of a property is intended to be used as part of the UI of an application, where null may lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing or erroneous user experience.

        Returns:
        A Double property that is a live view of this property.

      • viewAsInt

        default Val<java.lang.Integer> viewAsInt(java.util.function.Function<T,java.lang.Integer> mapper)
        Use this to create an Integer based live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function. So whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will be recomputed based on the result of the mapping function.

        Note that null references inside the viewed property will always be mapped to the "null object" of the Integer type, which is 0.
        This means that the resulting view can never contain null and its allowsNull() method will always return false.

        Null is deliberately avoided in the view because a view of a property is intended to be used as part of the UI of an application, where null may lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing or erroneous user experience.

        In case of an exception being thrown by the mapping function, the resulting view will also contain 0.

        Parameters:
        mapper - the mapping function to turn the item of this property to a Integer, if present
        Returns:
        A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

      • viewAsInt

        default Val<java.lang.Integer> viewAsInt()
        Use this to create an Integer based live view of this property through a new property based on the Object.toString() and Integer.parseInt(String) methods. If the String cannot be parsed to an Integer, the item of the property will be 0.

        Note that null references inside the viewed property will always be mapped to the "null object" of the Integer type, which is 0.
        This means that the resulting view can never contain null and its allowsNull() method will always return false.

        Null is deliberately avoided in the view because the view of a property is intended to be used as part of the UI of an application, where null may lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing or erroneous user experience.

        Returns:
        An Integer property that is a live view of this property.

      • itemAsString

        default java.lang.String itemAsString()
        This method simply returns a String representation of the wrapped item which would otherwise be accessed via the orElseThrow() method. Calling it should not have any side effects.
        The string conversion is based on the String.valueOf(Object) method, so if the item is null, the string "null" will be returned.
        Returns:
        The String representation of the item wrapped by an implementation of this interface.

      • typeAsString

        default java.lang.String typeAsString()
        This method returns a String representation of the type of the wrapped item. Calling it should not have any side effects.
        Returns:
        A simple String representation of the type of the item wrapped by an implementation of this interface.

      • is

        default boolean is(T otherItem)
        This method check if the provided item is equal to the item wrapped by this Var instance.
        Parameters:
        otherItem - The other item of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if the provided item is equal to the wrapped item.

      • is

        default boolean is(Val<T> other)
        This method check if the item by the provided property is equal to the item wrapped by this Var instance.
        Parameters:
        other - The other property of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if the item of the supplied property is equal to the wrapped item.

      • isNot

        default boolean isNot(T otherItem)
        This method check if the provided item is not equal to the item wrapped by this Val instance. This is the opposite of is(Object) which returns true if the items are equal.
        Parameters:
        otherItem - The other item of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if the provided item is not equal to the wrapped item.

      • isNot

        default boolean isNot(Val<T> other)
        This method check if the item of the provided property is not equal to the item wrapped by this Val instance. This is the opposite of is(Val) which returns true if the items are equal.
        Parameters:
        other - The other property of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if the item of the supplied property is not equal to the wrapped item.

      • isOneOf

        default boolean isOneOf(T first,
                        T second,
                        T... otherValues)
        This method checks if at least one of the provided items is equal to the item wrapped by this Var instance.
        Parameters:
        first - The first item of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        second - The second item of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        otherValues - The other items of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if the provided item is equal to the wrapped item.

      • isOneOf

        default boolean isOneOf(Val<T> first,
                        Val<T> second,
                        Val<T>... otherValues)
        This checks if at least one of the items of the provided properties is equal to the item wrapped by this Var instance.
        Parameters:
        first - The first property of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        second - The second property of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        otherValues - The other properties of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if the item of the supplied property is equal to the wrapped item.

      • id

        java.lang.String id()
        Returns the name/id of the property which is useful for debugging as well as persisting their state by using them as keys for whatever storage data structure one chooses.
        For example, when converting a property based model to a JSON object, the id of the properties can be used as keys in the JSON object.
        Returns:
        The id which is assigned to this property.

      • withId

        Val<T> withId(java.lang.String id)
        Use this method to create a new property with an id. This id is used to identify the property in the UI or as a key in a map, which is useful when converting your view model to a JSON object, or similar formats.

        You can retrieve the id of a property by calling the id() method.
        An id may not be null, please use the NO_ID constant or an empty string to indicate that a property has no id.

        Parameters:
        id - The id of the property, which is used to identify it. It may not be null, please use the NO_ID constant
        Returns:
        A new Val instance with the given id.

      • hasNoID

        default boolean hasNoID()
        A convenient method to check if this property has not been assigned an id.
        This is the same as calling !hasID() or id().equals(NO_ID).
        Returns:
        True when this property has not been assigned an id or the id is equal to the NO_ID constant.

      • hasID

        default boolean hasID()
        A convenient method to check if this property has been assigned an id.
        This is the same as calling !id().equals(NO_ID).
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if this property has been assigned an id, or if id is not equal to the NO_ID constant.

      • type

        java.lang.Class<T> type()
        This returns the type of the item wrapped by this Var which can be accessed by calling the orElseThrow() method.
        Returns:
        The type of the item wrapped by the Var.

      • toOptional

        default java.util.Optional<T> toOptional()
        Use this to turn this property to an Optional which can be used to interact with the item wrapped by this Val in a more functional way.
        Returns:
        An Optional wrapping the item wrapped by this Val.

      • onChange

        Val<T> onChange(Channel channel,
                Action<Val<T>> action)
        Use this to register an observer lambda for a particular Channel, which will be called whenever the item wrapped by this Val changes through the Var::set(Channel, T) method. The lambda will receive the current item of this property. The default channel is From.VIEW_MODEL, so if you use the Var::set(T) method then the observer lambdas registered through this method will be called.
        Parameters:
        channel - The channel from which the item is set.
        action - The lambda which will be called whenever the item wrapped by this Var changes.
        Returns:
        The Val instance itself.

      • fireChange

        Val<T> fireChange(Channel channel)
        Triggers all observer lambdas for the given Channel. Change listeners may be registered using the onChange(Channel, Action) method. Note that when the Var::set(T) method is called then this will automatically translate to fireChange(From.VIEW_MODEL). So it is supposed to be used by the view to update the UI components. This is in essence how binding works in Swing-Tree.
        Parameters:
        channel - The channel from which the item is set.
        Returns:
        The Val instance itself.

      • allowsNull

        boolean allowsNull()
        A property will only allow null items if it was constructed with a "ofNullable(..)" factory method. Otherwise, it will throw an IllegalArgumentException when trying to set a null reference. This flag cannot be changed after the property has been constructed!
        The purpose of this method is to warn the UI that this property can contain null items, so that it may throw an exception or do something else to handle this case. For many types of properties null is simply nonsensical, like String for example, where the absence of a value is represented by an empty string.
        Returns:
        true, if this property can contain null, false otherwise.

      • equals

        static boolean equals(@Nullable java.lang.Object o1,
                      @Nullable java.lang.Object o2)
        Val and Var implementations are expected to represent simple wrappers for data centric quasi value types! So two primitive arrays of integers for example would not be recognized as equal when calling one of their Object.equals(Object) methods because the method does not compare the contents of the two arrays, it compares the identities of the arrays! This method defines what it means for 2 property items to be equal. So in this example it ensures that two Var instances wrapping different arrays but with the same contents are treated as the same items.
        Parameters:
        o1 - The first object which ought to be compared to the second one.
        o2 - The second object which ought to be compared to the first one.
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if the objects are equal in terms of their state!

      • hashCode

        static int hashCode(java.lang.Object o)
        Val and Var implementations require their own Object.hashCode() method because they are supposed to be viewed as data centric quasi value types! So two arrays of integer for example would not have the same hash code when calling Object.hashCode() on them. This is because the method does not compare the contents of the two arrays!
        Parameters:
        o - The object for which a hash code is required.
        Returns:
        The hash code of the object.
